awd_titl_txt: Urban Massachusetts Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in order to diversify the STEM workforce.  Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy.  The Urban Massachusetts Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (UMLSAMP) program was established in 2007 in response to the need for a more diverse and skilled technical workforce.  That need still exists and is particularly acute in the Eastern Region of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.  Participating institutions include three University of Massachusetts campuses (Boston, Dartmouth and Lowell); Wentworth Institute of Technology; and four community college partners (Bristol, Bunker Hill, Middlesex, and Roxbury).  The UMLSAMP's goals are to increase the number of 1) Black, Hispanic, and Native American STEM students by 50%; 2) Baccalaureate STEM degrees awarded to Black, Hispanic, and Native American students by 150%; and 3) Students who successfully transfer from Alliance community colleges into BS STEM majors by 150%.  These goals support the National Science Foundation's strategic goal to "cultivate a world-class, broadly inclusive science and engineering workforce, and expand the scientific literacy of all citizens."  The goals will be accomplished by strategies based on the previous 10 years of Alliance experience to include but are not limited to:  Facilitated Study Groups, Supplemental Instruction, Research Skills Development Workshops, Mentored Research Experiences for Undergraduates in STEM, and Community Service Projects.

The knowledge generating research study will employ a multi-layered, mixed-methods design with the supposition that understanding the specific programmatic aspects that contribute to LSAMP's success, institutionalizing these at Alliance institutions, and replicating them across the higher education sector can make a significant contribution to diversifying the nation's STEM-skilled workforce in all fields.  Lessons learned and programmatic outcomes will be disseminated through online communication channels, participation in national and international student success and STEM related conferences and workshops, and peer-reviewed publications.  Progress towards project goals will be carefully tracked internally in accordance with the UMLSAMP Logical Model and through the engagement of an external evaluator.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report - 2017 - 2023

NSF Urban Massachusetts Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation

 

The NSF Urban Massachusetts Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (UM LSAMP) consists of eight universities and colleges in three major metropolitan areas in Eastern Massachusetts. Seven are public institutions of higher learning. Four members are associate degree granting community colleges that send a large number of their students to the other four institutions. These other four members of this Alliance are universities and colleges which grant baccalaureate degrees. The lead campus University of Massachusetts Boston (UMass Boston); the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth; the University of Massachusetts Lowell; Wentworth Institute of Technology; and the two-year institutions: Bristol; Bunker Hill; Middlesex; and Roxbury community colleges. Leadership for UM LSAMP comes from Joseph B. Berger, Provost and PI; Robin Côté, Dean of the College of Science and Mathematics and co-Pl; and Marshall Milner, Program Manager. Celebrating its 15th year, UM LSAMP has helped to significantly enhance retention, persistence, and graduation rates in STEM majors through various impactful and inclusive student activities and services.

 

UM LSAMP program’s main emphasis was on the development of a robust academic foundation for students underrepresented in STEM. By employing cohort-based learning, collaborative instructional methods, and block scheduling in some instances, UM LSAMP has created dynamic learning communities. These communities were adaptable, transitioning to virtual formats during the COVID-19 pandemic. Integral to this approach were facilitated study groups, supplemental instruction sessions, research skills development workshops, and mentored undergraduate research experiences. These support systems helped foster academic excellence and prepare students for advanced research and professional STEM roles.

 

UM LSAMP's commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion has led to more inclusive STEM pedagogy and research practices, improved engagement and support for a diverse student body, and notably higher retention and success rates among underrepresented minorities. The curriculum's intellectual rigor has been enhanced by integrating diverse perspectives, making it more accessible and holistic. Inclusive teaching practices among faculty have been cultivated, and research opportunities focusing on diversity within STEM have been expanded, enriching institutional knowledge among the Alliance members.

 

UM LSAMP has been instrumental in institutionalizing effective and inclusive student support models. These initiatives include Facilitated Study Groups, Supplemental Instruction Sessions offering course credits, and Pre-Calculus workshops. Additionally, STEM Clubs and chapters of societies like the National Society of Black Engineers and the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers have seen active participation from LSAMP leaders. This involvement has led to a significant institutional impact, with many programs now receiving funding from general institutional budgets, marking a substantial shift in how institutions support and engage their STEM students.

 

The UM LSAMP Alliance has established strong connections with industry representatives to help foster a more diverse STEM workforce. This leadership has also allowed UM LSAMP campuses to secure additional support for internships and STEM training equipment from key organizations in Massachusetts, including the Massachusetts Life Sciences Center, the Massachusetts Biotechnology Organization, and the Massachusetts Technology Collaborative. The influx of resources and partnerships has enhanced UM LSAMP's capabilities, leading to more training workshops, off-campus internships, and deeper student engagement with STEM professionals in Massachusetts.

 

The UM LSAMP program played an instrumental role in UMass Boston's inclusion in the Northeast Microelectronics Coalition Hub. This involvement strengthens UMass Boston and the UM LSAMP Alliance's roles in engineering training and recruitment for the expanding semiconductor and microelectronics industries. UM LSAMP students are anticipated to benefit greatly from enhanced educational and internship opportunities, preparing them to meet the evolving demands of STEM job market.

 

The UM LSAMP’s involvement in a Subaward under the NSF INCLUDES grant to Northeastern University, as part of the New England Regional Hub, aims to significantly broaden the impact on diversity in engineering. This initiative is a collaborative effort between Urban Massachusetts LSAMP, Northeast LSAMP, and others, focusing on increasing BIPOC and women engineers' numbers. The NSF INCLUDES Alliance's goal is to raise the national count of engineering degrees and establish sustained growth. The collaboration, including conferences and networking, is set to share best practices across the region, emphasizing broader impact and diversity.

 

In summary, NSF Urban Massachusetts LSAMP program has made significant contributions in both intellectual merit and broader societal impact generated by the Alliance institutions. Its efforts have enhanced various institutional and societal facets, demonstrating a substantial influence on STEM education and workforce development. The UM LSAMP members gained deeper insights into effective recruitment and support strategies for a diverse STEM student body. The UM LSAMP helped strengthen industry relationships, promoting a diverse STEM workforce, and developing strategies for scalable growth in internships and job opportunities. These efforts have profoundly influenced institutional knowledge and the future diverse STEM workforce, contributing to global competitiveness and national security.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2023
Modified by: Robin J Cote
